info.game_comments:
2005 College Championship semifinal game 1.
From the RBC Center in Raleigh, North Carolina.

(1, 1).clue: This country's new president Ahmadinejad may have minored in embassy hostage taking in the 1970s

(2, 1).clue: This 1999 movie says it's the footage shot by 3 film students who disappeared in the Maryland woods

(3, 1).clue: Judith Miller got nailed in the Plamegate scandal while reporting for this newspaper

(4, 1).clue: Bloody Romanian prince known as "the Impaler"

(5, 1).clue: At Texas A&M civil engineering majors can take a course called advanced design in this "reinforced" paving material

(6, 1).clue: Philander C. Knox, Daniel Webster & John Foster Dulles have all held this federal post

(1, 2).clue: 12 years after approving NAFTA, Congress barely passed this trade deal opening southern markets

(2, 2).clue: When Kate Hudson unlocks a hidden attic room that has a terrifying secret, she uses the title object of this 2005 film

(3, 2).clue: This CBS anchor got hammered in 2004 reporting on President Bush's military service

(4, 2).clue: He was "the Confessor" king of England in the 11th century

(5, 2).clue: This University of Nebraska at Omaha offers an English course devoted to this "Canterbury Tales" author

(6, 2).clue: President Clinton recognized Hank Aaron's achievements in this January 27, 2000 speech
(6, 2).correct response: the State of the Union address

(1, 3).clue: On Sept. 28, 2005 he stepped down as House Majority Leader (at least temporarily) upon being indicted

(2, 3).clue: It's terror at 30,000 feet for Rachel McAdams in this 2005 film that's like "Phone Booth" on a plane

(3, 3).clue: In 2003 this Caribbean island nation put 27 reporters in the slammer for furthering U.S. interests

(5, 3).clue: At N.Y.'s Vassar global feminism & postmodern feminism are 2 of the courses offered in this program

(6, 3).clue: From the Latin for "laid waste", it means to destroy

(1, 4).clue: Napster's gone legit, but the Supreme Court ruled against this file-sharing company in MGM Studios v. it

(2, 4).clue: Elisha Cuthbert & Paris Hilton are amazed by the life-like sculptures at this title museum

(3, 4).clue: This editor had "Common Sense" but he was arrested while in France for opposing Louis XVI's execution

(4, 4).clue: Basil "the Bulgar-Slayer" was emperor of this, also called the Eastern Roman Empire

(5, 4).clue: Here at N.C. State you can find a course on "The Life and Letters of" this apostle from Tarsus

(6, 4).clue: Numerical term used to describe the press

(1, 5).clue: (Hi, I'm Nancy Grace with CNN Headline News.)  On a busy March 16, 2005, I reported on Scott Peterson's death sentence & this actor's murder acquittal

(2, 5).clue: A cross of horror & western, "The Devil's Rejects" was written & directed by this shock rocker

(3, 5).clue: Ca.'s Liberty Hill was so named because in 1923 this muckraker & "Jungle" author was arrested at a union rally there

(4, 5).clue: Holy Roman emperor Charles II was known by this nickname; today we might call him "the Follicularly Challenged"

(5, 5).clue: Biology majors at Humboldt might take mammalogy, herpetology or this, the study of fish

(6, 5).clue: This term means not having made a will

(1, 1).clue: 2005 marks 150 years since this poet first mowed his "Leaves of Grass"

(2, 1).clue: "You better lose yourself in the music, the moment, you own it you better never let it go"

(4, 1).clue: Riding these, Cody Hancock's specialty, is considered by many to be the most dangerous rodeo event

(5, 1).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew points to paints & pigments.)  "The clash of colors, like the different greens,  express the terrible passions of humanity", wrote this artist

(1, 2).clue: "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock" asks, "Shall I part my hair behind?  Do I dare to eat" this fruit

(2, 2).clue: "It's gettin' hot in here (so hot), so take off all your clothes"

(4, 2).clue: More shark attacks occur in the waters off this country than any other

(5, 2).clue: In his "Night Watch", hierarchy is shown by the shadow of the militia captain's hand on an underling's coat

(6, 2).clue: A dark rye bread that originated in Germany

(1, 3).clue: In 1993 she became the second poet to recite an original work at a presidential inauguration

(2, 3).clue: "Sippin' on gin & juice, laid back, with my mind on my money and my money on my mind"

(4, 3).clue: According to Homer, these deadly mythological singers enticed many a sailor to his doom

(5, 3).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew poses with a Pontormo painting.)  As painters often do, Pontormo inserted one of these into his work called "Deposition"

(6, 3).clue: A single amount of money that serves as a complete payment

(1, 4).clue: In a Keats ode, these 5 words immediately precede "that is all ye know on Earth, and all ye need to know"

(2, 4).clue: "Your mom busted in and said 'What's that noise?', aw Mom, you're just jealous, it's" them

(4, 4).clue: In the first Time magazine in 1923, these below-ground workers protested dangerous work conditions

(5, 4).clue: The message of healing in Friedrich's "Winter Landscape" includes a discarded pair of these supports

(6, 4).clue: Asian national capital city with a 2-word name

(1, 5).clue: This poem by Matthew Arnold mentions the French coast & the cliffs of England

(2, 5).clue: "I been here for years, rockin' my peers & puttin' suckas in fear... Mama said knock you out"

(4, 5).clue: Due to storms, the southernmost cape of South America is one of the world's most dangerous places

(5, 5).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew poses with a seascape.)  W.H. Auden wrote, "Everything turns away quite leisurely from a disaster" in Bruegel's "Landscape with the Fall of" this mythical flier

(6, 5).clue: Term for Republicans who abandoned their own party in 1884 to support Grover Cleveland

(0, 0).clue: A Phillips 66 in Cloquet, Minnesota is the only functioning gas station designed by this man
